Overall, this is a good course for introducing the basics. However, the 2 parts I was really looking forward to: generics and module declarations were just glossed over. In these areas, the learner is simply instructed to use Google or read the docs. That disappointed me because I find the TS docs to be particularly poor. That is why I bought this course.

Really liked the way the course was delivered, but the content didn't really cover the bases I hoped it would.

results.content: Good foundational overview of TS. Learned a lot and Maximillian does a great job of thoroughly explaining everything with a good attitude and engaging voice. Would have liked to see more real-world examples in the later sections. Specifically on decorators and React. The webpack tooling sections ought to be updated. I know this was not a TS & React course, but I was a bit let down since there were hardly any examples of using TS in React code. If we had walked through even a simple app in React and shown how to leverage TS in React and some basic use cases this would easily get 5 stars. After all a good final project to cap off and allow students to use all of the techniques they've just learned to create something really would have driven the concepts home. A missed opportunity for certain in my opinion.

results.content:
Definitely a code-along course. There are only a few moments where you are encouraged to attempt to write code on your own, and then check your work with his solution, otherwise it's just him blazing through the material as you try to keep up coding with him. Also, he regularly has a lot of code in his files which he scrolls around quickly while explaining concepts, which resulted in unnecessary confusion (e.g. - instructor says something, you look down at your code to implement what he's talking about, look up at the screen, and he's scrolled to somewhere else completely different in his file).

The course seemed thorough, but without the opportunity to actually practice the concepts, I don't feel very well equipped to start programming with TS. Oh well. . . I guess I'll just have to practice on my own! ;)
results.content_html:
Definitely a code-along course. There are only a few moments where you are encouraged to attempt to write code on your own, and then check your work with his solution, otherwise it's just him blazing through the material as you try to keep up coding with him. The course seemed thorough, but without the opportunity to actually practice the concepts, I don't feel very well equipped to start programming with TS. Oh well. . . I guess I'll just have to practice on my own! ;)

results.content:
Max is a great instructor. He breaks down things very efficiently. What I like about his way of teaching, is that he makes sure to mention edge case as he explains things, even though he doesn't implement those edge cases.
It's great, because once you build something, you sometimes run into bugs and have no idea why they happen. They often happen because of some edge cases that other instructors don't always bother to explain.

Overall I'd definitely recommend this course for anyone with JS background that wants to get familiar with TS as well.

* Definitely learn JS first if you don't already know it.

results.content:
I've followed Max' React course, which is of extremely high quality, so my expectations to this course were high. 

Unfortunately I don't feel this course lived up to my high expectations. While it did cover all of the typescript functionality, it didn't go deep enough into each concept, so now by the end, I don't feel much wiser than I was at the beginning. 

There was som nice assignments in the beginning, but unfortunately, there wasn't any by the end. There could definitely have been more assignments. 

I came mainly for using with typescript with react, and that module was good I thought, even it was a little outdated, but much too brief. We didn't really learn how to work with the different type definitions of react. I did think the setup part and configuration of webpack was good though. 

As always Max is very enthusiastic and a good teacher, but the audio quality could have been better, and it's hard to look at that IDE after the beauty of Visual Studio Code. 

As a total intro to TS this is a good course, if you're looking to learn it in conjunction with a framework or if you already know the basics, I would look elsewhere.

results.content:
I have very mixed feelings about this course. 

The majority of what TypeScript introduces to JavaScript are concepts found in other strongly typed languages like C++ or Java. Developers already familiar with typing or object-oriented programming will likely find more benefit in this course than those not familiar.

I think the instructor did an adequate job covering the basic concepts introduced in TypeScript. What I didn't like was that the teaching code and exercises were too simplistic. The instructor doesn't build upon previous lessons or demonstrate everything coming together in any "real-world" project. 

These sort of teaching techniques are a great way to demonstrate best practices with the language and gives the student an opportunity to build something more useful. The lack of any such project was disappointing.

The course also felt rushed. For a developer with typed language experience that wants to learn the TypeScript syntax quickly, it's excellent. Developers new to these concepts will miss out on the lack of experience-based guidance that the instructor most surely has.

The other annoying issue I had was that some videos and sections have become pretty outdated. TypeScript and the associated packages used in the course have evolved. While a handful of lectures have helpful "things have changed" notices preceding them, I ran into a number of errors and unexpected behavior that I had to find workarounds in the Q/A section.

Overall I liked the course but did not find nearly as much value in it as I had hoped.

results.content:
This is a very nice introduction to TypeScript. Not only does Max take us through all the important features of the language, but also how to use it real projects. My favourite was the part where he explained workflows using tsc, gulp and webpack. Also, the section about react.js is good enough to get you started with basic react + TypeScript. This gave me a very clear understanding and I hope I can use this in my future JavaScript courses, like react, PWAs etc.

I wish there was a full fledged project using TypeScript, where I could apply all the knowledge I gained. The exercises were useful, but a project always helps.

results.content:
Due to my job I had to do with Angular and NestJS which both build upon TypeScript. Therefore I decided to give this course a try to really understand the basics of TypeScript although I knew quite a few things beforehand. Nevertheless I think that the course helped me to get an even better understanding of how TypeScript works and what you can do with it. Max is a great instructor, covers and explains a lot of the language features. I especially like that the course also looks outside of the nutshell by showing how to use JS frameworks/libraries (jquery and react) with TypeScript so you also get to know how you can use the language in practice.

However, I think there are also some points which prevent me from giving a full five star rating. One is that the course does not mention "ts-node" which is really helpful to run TS files and gives better output than the approach shown by Max where every TS gets compiled to a JS and then executed in the browser (where console.out() can only be viewed in development view). I also miss some explanations about the version history of TS. The course had some updates but it looks like it does not cover TS version 3 at all. Also some of the examples do not work right away (due to using old versions of dependencies/tools) and you need to check forums or google to find out, how to make it work.

So although the course does not seem to be completly up to date, I would recommend it for anyone who is interested in learning the basics of TypeScript.

results.content:
This course offers you a great knowledge about TypeScript. And as a bonus it also has React + TS examples and NodeJS + TS examples which would help you from bottom!

About the author:  
Max really done a great job with his courses, he always remind people on how to do things differently, also keeps reminding people that "this method" has been taught earlier. And even so, he keep explaining the method again. So this is very good if you're a beginner. But of course, you need to learn Javascript first before doing this.

The cons of this course is, this is a "Beginner" to "Middle" course. Max keep repeating the same thing which would seem to be redundant if you're actually a quick learner, thus also making the video longer.

But hey, if you're fine with that, then this is the right course for you.

results.content:
Very clear explanations, meaningful code-alongs and exercises, and the instructor's enthusiasm is infectious. Plus, the presentation is very smooth and looks/sounds quite professional.

My only thought on areas for improvement had to do with the last few modules, where the videos seemed to refer to older package versions and things don't quite behave the same way now. I'd have appreciated some explanations of this and revised instructions (even if just written) before any such affected videos. Also, the "solve for yourself" exercises with a follow-up video solution just disppeared in the later modules. Perhaps this just goes with the nature of those modules, but they were very helpful in the earlier modules.

results.content:
I got this course because we'll start using TypeScript and ReactJS in one of my work projects. I figured this course would help me understand the syntax and capabilities of TS.

A few notes that would make this course even better:
1. add a few more exercises

2. split up the examples into several files in order to make it easier to see where the previous lesson left off and the current one started

3. many of the variable names in the examples were similar to each other and easy to mix up. maybe use a bigger variety of variable names


All in all, the course was good and contained everything I expected.
7 hours (plus exercises) well spent!
results.content_html:

results.content:
The course is pretty good. It certainly requires that you have at least some prior JS knowledge but if you do, you'll enjoy the course.
I gave a 4 as in the drag and drop project I felt there was too little space for experiment. I tried to go my own way and ended up with a broken project. That's unfortunate but everything else was really good.
I already used TS in my work but I felt that I didn't use it to full potential and now I see lots of space for improvement there thanks to this course :)

An example from another page explaining it is https://codeburst.io/decorate-your-code-with-typescript-decorators-5be4a4ffecb4. But overall, I am happy with the course content I covered so far. Thank you.

results.content:
I started using Typescript with React in a project but got stuck many times and working through the docs was very dry, so I looked for video courses and found this one. 
After working my way through this course I have now a much better understanding and working with Typescript is very enjoyable now.
My only critique is that the first half of the course is very dry to follow as there is no practice time. He talks through all the different types and options and does include small quizzes at the end of each section, but I would love to see some coding challenges, to make it easier to remember the material and make it more fun and interactive.

results.content:
Max did a really good job explaining and breaking down the concepts in each module. Good job on that!

I wish there were more exercises - about 5 exercises per module would have hit the sweet spot.

I was also very interested in the React/Typescript module - however the content here was very disappointing as it was mainly concerned with the project setup (the TS team has a more up-to-date guide on that here: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/react-&-webpack.html) and not that extensively with the actual React library itself.

results.content: I think this was very helpful.  I know that the typical course protocol calls for modules with introductions and conclusions along with a course introduction and conclusion.  However, I find them all redundant, and I skip them to get to the actual content of the various modules.  Because of this, I don't show as having completed the course.  It would be nice if these "Let me tell you want I'm going to tell you", and "Let me tell you what I just told you" lectures could be marked as optional or something like that.  If that were the case, I wouldn't have to waste my time in order to achieve a "completed" course.

results.content:
If you are thinking to know what typescript is and its basics then this course can help you in that regard. Some chapter gives you an example challenge to solve it first before checking the solution. This could help get some grasp of concepts. If you are thinking this course will cover advanced topics then this course is not for you. If you have some experience in Object Oriented Programming then it could even be a plus. Some of my comments about why I gave this rating are as follows:

- Until Section 7 things seem to make sense and they are quite easy to understand if a totally new guy (with little programming experience) wants to give it a try. 

- Section 8 and 9 explanation could have been better. Generics and Decorators are two big things in TypeScript.  There I felt that things could have been told in a more practical way and with more details. As these two topics can be daunting for newbies. Sometimes only giving links to official documents can't help people rather this could make them more confused.

- Overall this course could have been much better if there was the addition of an example walkthrough tutorial of a fully working application. I feel the example of React could have been replaced with a better explanation of the more advanced topics in TypeScript. That uses all the concepts presented in the course. This would have given a practical perspective on how to use the different capabilities of TypeScript.

results.content:
The instructor is absolutely great with editing his videos and presents the material in a manner which which is both prepared and professional.  I have learned so much in the first couple of hours in the course through the provided "hands on" examples than I have reading both a book and the documentation.

The exercises are great, they test each of the 'sticky' points you learn throughout the course and ensure you can apply the material to what was taught in the module.  The exercises are simple, but they give you the tools you need to tackle larger projects.

I love the developer's enthusiasm and knowledge of the material, definitely one of the best Udemy courses I have taken so far, I am going to purchase the ES6 course mentioned in one of the lectures, just to make sure I round out the knowledge that overlaps from this course on TypeScript.

Top notch, Instructor gets a solid 'A' from me.

Go learn yourself some JavaScript and comeback later. Besides that Max really is a great instructor, his explanations are clear and help you really understand what he's talking about.

results.content:
Max is obviously an experienced programmer, but the way he explains things causes too much confusion, in my opinion. A lot of this has to do with the general pace, which is quite quick. I wish he would slow down a little and keep things simpler. I'm sure most of us would learn more.

The introductions and summaries also don't make much sense as they are basically a long list of the topics covered in that section without any useful information. What is anyone supposed to learn from this? It just makes me more confused.

results.content:
This is my third course from Max. Max is a really good instructor and his React and Vue courses are top quality with in-depth explanations and lot of real word examples. Max also always keep his courses up to date.

This course however falls short to satisfy me. This course only covers the different features TypeScript has to offer without diving into real world usage. I am not the only one who felt this. I saw a lot of lecture videos had questions by other students on real world usage of the covered topic.

These kind of courses are not new though. This has become the norm, where people on YouTube and any other online learning platform upload videos covering just the content topics from the official documentation of the language they are teaching.

On Udemy, instructors should check out the course material of Java Masterclass course by Tim Buchalka. That course covers the language completely with lot of examples and real world usage of the various features Java has to offer.

This course might be the best course on TypeScript on Udemy but I would still rate it 2/5.

results.content:
Excellent!!! I like the way the information is taught. He teaches concepts. 
For instance, in the Modules section, Max will make a change and it doesn't work. He explains why and makes another change - the code fails. These are the errors that a person like myself would normally make. It helps to understand what is going on "under the hood". Any instructor can give you the correct answer. He walks through the code at the "student's pace". Baby steps.
My opinion - it is not for a beginner programmer. Learn beginner JavaScript and HTML. That should suffice.
Also, expect to pause the video a often!!! It is a lot of useful information with no "fluff". 

Thanks Max for taking the time to do it right!

FYI: I am off to taking another course from Max - Angular. It is based on Typescript. I'm ready...

results.content:
This course is fricking awesome! I've been trying for a while now to learn Typescript (because I want to learn Angular) using a book I bought as well as online resources, and while I did manage to figure some things out, there was really no proper structure to it, and it took a lot of time to look for answers, time I didn't really have. I had no real understanding of how it was all connected, and being a self-taught developer, my intermediate JavaScript knowledge kept getting in the way of my understanding how TypeScript is "same same, but different" as it were.

I stumbled onto a preview video of Max' Angular-course on YouTube, and quickly found that the way he presents the material is pretty much perfect for my taste (and he's german, which always equals top quality in this part of the world). Because of that I came here to sign up for his Angular 4 course, but in so doing I found this TypeScript course and decided to go through that first, and I'm really glad I made that decision.

Thanks to Max, TypeScript to me is no longer a wobbling mess of almost-JavaScript that's somehow supposed to work and make sense just because of reasons :)

results.content:
It was fun to learn and see how it applied to JavaScript. The lectures were structured very well to understand the relationship between the two. 

The only issue is that there was a lot of bouncing around in the explanation of concepts in terms of the assumed level of JavaScript that the student knew. For the most part this wasn't an issue, but in the second half of the lecture it seemed like the level of JavaScript knowledge needed shot up, therefore those sections seemed a little rushed. As a disclaimer, my experience with JS is that I have studied it and used it in the past and look at it almost every day at work/sometimes troubleshoot it, but I haven't actually written many projects with it lately - not sure if that's where the gap lies.

results.content:
I liked the course a lot and it fully met my expectations.  Max explains the concepts very well, it is easy to follow and understand.  What I liked a lot is the fact that Max showed how to use TypeScript with other third party (JavaScript) libraries such as JQuery and React and showed how to use it in workflows (Gulp and Webpack). 
Given the date of when the course was created (2016?) and the fast progression in web development, I had difficulties to follow the more advanced videos as certain things are outdated or have changed meanwhile (as of 2019).  To implement the examples on your own can then become a bit of a harder exercise.  Besides this, well done!

results.content:
My first language (after basic) was Java. Then I went on to learn ES5 and ES6 alongside with Angular/Ionic (version 1) as well as NodeJS, Express and Mongo. 

Learning Typescript in this course was like coming home with types, interfaces, abstract classes, classes as well as generics. I got inspired. From this perspective the information in this course was very valuable.

The explanations of concepts were clear to me as someone who has experience with Java. The hardest parts, though, were Gulp and Webpack together with Typescript, which I will review again. 

The instructor seemed excited, coupled with his knowledge about the subject of Typescript. This made the delivery engaging.

There were exercises, some of which took me a while to figure out (read: they were good opportunities to learn). 

A very good course all in all - more than just an introduction to Typescript. Now I'm ready to embedd the Typescript (OOP, Strong Types, transpilation) approach to other projects.

Thank you Max for giving me inspiration!
results.content_html:
My first language (after basic) was Java. Then I went on to learn ES5 and ES6 alongside with Angular/Ionic (version 1) as well as NodeJS, Express and Mongo.

Learning Typescript in this course was like coming home with types, interfaces, abstract classes, classes as well as generics. I got inspired. From this perspective the information in this course was very valuable.

The explanations of concepts were clear to me as someone who has experience with Java. The hardest parts, though, were Gulp and Webpack together with Typescript, which I will review again.

The instructor seemed excited, coupled with his knowledge about the subject of Typescript. This made the delivery engaging.

There were exercises, some of which took me a while to figure out (read: they were good opportunities to learn).

A very good course all in all - more than just an introduction to Typescript. Now I'm ready to embedd the Typescript (OOP, Strong Types, transpilation) approach to other projects.

Thank you Max for giving me inspiration!

results.content: Great course.  Got me up and running with TypeScript much more efficiently than if I was piecing together youtube videos/tutorials.  Max is a wonderful instructor, and was very responsive to questions I asked during the course.  If you want to dive deep into TypeScript, and come away with skills that you can immediately begin applying to real-world projects, I'd highly recommend this course.

results.content:
I decided to take this course as a prerequisite for Angular study to have a better understanding of what's going on in tutorials TypeScript wise. And I got what I came for with clear instructions.

Sure, you can get it all from official documentation, but this course is a great way to speed up adoption of basic concepts and be on your way.

I would give it a 5 star if it had more real world examples of application.

Summary: I recommend this course to anybody who wants to quickly start working with TS on itself or with other frameworks.

Je suis étudiant résidant en France et j'ai suivi avec intérêt votre cours d'initiation sur TypeScript. Je n'ai pas tout compris ce que vous avez expliqué à cause de mon anglais que je ne maitrise pas bien encore.

Malgré tout, j'ai suivi jusqu'au bout vos tutoriel et testé le code de chaque module au fur et à mesure.

Maintenant que j'ai quelques bases en TypeScript, j'espère pouvoir suivre vos prochains tutoriels sur Angular2. :-)

Yours faifully.


Antoine NOUVENE from France

results.content: Some of the examples may be a little bit confusing for beginners (like using const for the example variables instead of let), and the provided zipped codes should be updated to the latest available version of Webpack and Typescript, as for example the zipped React example didn't run with the provided package.json and webpack.config.js files. Other than these very small issues, the course is very good and covered a lot of area that I didn't know before (like SystemJS and Webpack).

Other than these very small issues, the course is very good and covered a lot of area that I didn't know before (like SystemJS and Webpack).

results.content: Грамотный преподаватель, приятно слушать. Курс понравился, начал внедрять в React-приложении, нужно конечно немного пошаманить, но работает хорошо, не понимаю, как я раньше жил без строгой типизации, очень полезно. В курсе есть все основы, необходимые для понимания и написания типизированного кода на TypeScript, лекции не длинные, есть тесты на понимание лекций. Тема джейнериков затронута простыми примерами, для более сложных - нужно изучать самостоятельно, тем не менее, понимание дает. Перегрузка функций/методов практически не затрагивалась в рамках курса. В любом случае, отличный и грамотно построенный курс, советую к изучению. В конце немного про использование совместно с React. Спасибо Max!

results.content: The instruction is easy to understand and the material is very focused for each lesson.  I did have to do most of my listening at 1.5x speed, for my personal taste in cadence.  The video quality for lesson 132 was out of focus, but I trust the instructor will correct this.  The material was a good introduction to  the features of typescript.  You should have a background in Javascript and some OO concepts beforehand.  Would have appreciated a round-up project module at the end that tied everything together in a mini app.

results.content: In my opinion, this is the ideal course for learning TS in depth. Max takes you through setting a barebones dev env for compiling TS, writing TS without leveraging any major frameworks, and then building a non-trivial React application with it. Upon completing this course, I felt I had learned just about everything I needed to learn in order to use Typescript effectively in my work.
results.content_html: In my opinion, this is the ideal course for learning TS in depth. Max takes you through setting a barebones dev env for compiling TS, writing TS without leveraging any major frameworks, and then building a non-trivial React application with it. Upon completing this course, I felt I had learned just about everything I needed to learn in order to use Typescript effectively in my work.

results.content: Detailing was missing. This is not for beginners. There is a lot of terminology not explained and this course explains the typescript features that's it not how typescript behind the scenes executes these features and why it works that way. I felt groundwork was missing.Coming to support, When I post any query in Q&A most of the times I get an alternative solution instead of solving it as it is. sometimes I receive incomplete solutions. Getting back a quick response is appreciated but to have the doubt completely solved is quite an important thing to progress in your programming career.

results.content:
Unfortunately, I have to say I'm disappointed. After angular course, I was expecting much more from Max.

The problem with this course is, that it's just basic. There are no in depth explanations, no advanced use cases, just the bare minimum. If you worked with angular, you already learned most of it just by doing it.

I bought this course to further my knowledge, to understand TS better and to see how to deal with more advanced interfaces and use cases. But I didn't find it here.

results.content: There are too few Typescript courses on here. I took this course because I really needed it but Max doesn't really know the deeper parts of typescript so his coverage of this course was very shallow. Stephen Grider's typescript course is the one you'll want. It goes very deep. I think that Max should get that one and learn how to make this course more in-depth. On most web technologies topics, Max does much better.

response.content: I'm sorry to hear you didn't enjoy this course. This course indeed is not bloated to be as long as possible but to be very concise. Don't mistake that with me "not knowing enough". I don't create courses to show off my developer skills but to teach you things. I understand that you're looking for a longer course and I'm happy you found one.

results.content:
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

A great course in which in-depth knowledge of the TypeScript programming language is disseminated in a well-organized fashion.

The course takes the student by the hand and, progressively, guide the student through the building-blocks of the TypeScript programming language preparing the student for the advanced topics within the language.

Some of the sections alone are worth the prices of the course itself, particularly the section on generics and decorators.

THIS COURSE IS A MUST for any serious JavaScript developer who wants to stay in the cutting-edge.

results.content:
Really great course. Very detailed, and well explained.

A couple of things may be outdated. The new versions of webpack and webpack-dev-server use publicPath differently, and html/css need to be placed in a Public folder by default. For noobs, setting up a project from scratch just like you did won't work, and the browser just shows a blank page and a 404.

For the GoogleMaps example, maybe use an alternative that does not require a sign up and credit card by default. Most people would not want to create a GCP account when they're starting out. It wastes their signup bonus. Try Nominatim (based on OpenStreetMaps) or MapQuest or positionstack, they don't require credit cards for signup. All three have GeoCoding APIs.

Anyway, thanks a lot for the course.
results.content_html:
Really great course. Very detailed, and well explained.

A couple of things may be outdated. The new versions of webpack and webpack-dev-server use publicPath differently, and html/css need to be placed in a Public folder by default. For noobs, setting up a project from scratch just like you did won't work, and the browser just shows a blank page and a 404.

For the GoogleMaps example, maybe use an alternative that does not require a sign up and credit card by default. Most people would not want to create a GCP account when they're starting out. It wastes their signup bonus. Try Nominatim (based on OpenStreetMaps) or MapQuest or positionstack, they don't require credit cards for signup. All three have GeoCoding APIs.

Anyway, thanks a lot for the course.

results.content:
Pros and Cons:

Cons:
* This course has pretty much no forced exercises whatsoever. (Number of exercises is typically a good sign of a teacher understanding the importance of them)
* The small quizzes are pointless tbh
* There is often not the best names for variables and methods
* He needs to work on providing better realistic examples (not "Animal" and "Bird" classes..)

Pros:
* He is good at explaining
* Brings up many different aspects of TypeScript
* Talks a lot about the configs
* Very good to show React and Node TS integration
* Does not waste as much time as many Udemy courses do on repeating or irrelevant info

Also unclear where TypeScript is going with namespaces. Used a much newer version of TS and found namespaces very flaky, especially when using WebPack, and only worked fully when using tsc command line and specifying all the input files to merge. Still, I learned a lot, so thanks Max

results.content:
Max is hands down the best instructor I've found, for example, I hadn't really used spread operators before. He explained it so perfectly with an example that just made sense straight away. Then he went on to show how it can be used on objects to solve an issue I've had before where the memory pointer is copied and not the actual object, in the solutions I found on StackOverflow nobody bought this method up and it would have saved me an incredible amount of time.

This is just one example, but if you take this course you will learn things that would otherwise catch you out if you didn't have Max providing clear and easy to understand examples of when it will cause a problem.

I was ecstatic to see he also has a course on Svelte, can't wait to finish this course so I can start that one.

results.content:
This is an excellent course on TypeScript and I'm very satisfied I invested in the material! Max takes the time to go in-depth about everything that TypeScript has to offer in a way that's easy to follow and keep up. I honestly never thought that TypeScript would substantially improve my developer experience in so many subtle but HUGE ways.

For my second project with TypeScript, I'm porting a website I built in Gatsby.Js and JavaScript to Next.Js and TypeScript. Even during the first project, the amount of time I'm wasting to leave my IDE and do some good ole 'How to fix *error message*?' or 'How does *library/framework* work?' googling had dropped a ton! I can hold my focus much longer and enter a development flow without interruptions more quickly.

Der Kurs trifft genau mein Ersuchen: das erlernen der Typescript Syntax.
Jedoch sollte man auch bedenken, dass Typescript eine Erweiterung zu Javascript ist und logischerweise Elemente aus Javascript, welche nicht in Typescript verändert wurden, in diesem Kurs nicht behandelt werden.

- Aktueller Stand: 50% des Kurses

results.content:
Good videos, good exercises.  Two issues with it:
- After Section 7 (Interfaces), I really didn't find much useful content.  Specifically, I have no idea why I would ever use a Generic or (especially) a Decorator.  Things like Classes, Namespaces, and Modules are fairly easy to grasp, but these two things are a mystery as to why they are of use.  I imagine this is because I'm not grasping the concept of these high-level ideas.  Perhaps more time should be spent on the high-level ideas giving real-world examples as opposed to the fairly simple script Max is creating (which works very well for earlier sections).
- Some videos flicker between the content and something in the background (Section 8, Lecture 91 is an example).  Not sure if it's my connection or something else going on.

results.content:
I did it :D! It was a great course all along, I now understand typescript's concepts even though it's quite a lot to take in but fortunately Maximilian did a great job with his good mood.

As a fullstack JS developper oriented React ( junior one ) I took this course to 
strengthen my JS skills, have the understanding of typescript in order to apply it and which I did through the last sessions' project as mentioned within the description.
I was easily abled to adapts the freshly new typescript's notions I just acquired with React and its last version (16.8), because I mainly understood this very typescript course by doing the classic React environment covered here. ( React 16.8 been freshly released ( about 2 months ago ) ).
This course get you a general knowledge of Typescript for a better practice and understanding, now we just have to practice it in our own project and get deeper in the official documentation for each specific needs !

results.content: This course taught me a great deal of what i believed are essentially the crux of Typescript, not just the language itself, but also its relation to external entities like SystemJs, Gulp and Webpack, and presented in a coherent manner, something which i have searched much to angst on google... I highly recommend this course to anybody wanting to learn Typescript, and its workings with SystemJs, Webpack. It has benefited me greatly.

results.content:
After doing this course I'm also now applying Typescript to applications written outside of Angular, in NodeJS etc. which makes a real difference to speed of development, reducing run-time bugs, and producing clear, maintainable code.

The course also shows how Typescript can be used with existing build systems such as Gulp and Webpack. Sometimes these integrations aren't the easiest things to do.

This is a good course, nicely paced, clearly explained, and the exercises ensure you grasp each concept before moving onto the next module. I really enjoyed the course

results.content:
I like how the course is kept quite simple and fast-paced. I already know programming so for me it's an optimal pacing.
The lectures are easy to understand and provide a good example of the TypeScript features.

A negative point for me is that the lectures are kept very small and handle just one subject. So far so good but there is always a little gap at the start and the end of the lecture that could have been avoided. It would make the flow of the course a bit faster.

results.content: I came to this course having has some exposure to Typescript, but wanting to understand why I was doing some of the things I was doing. For this, I found this course to be excellent. I thought it was pitched at just the right level for me, and the lessons were concise enough to pick up the knowledge I needed without it getting lost in "fluff". I liked the presenters approach to the lessons, and thought the examples he chose in the latter lessons to well thought out and a useful reference to getting up and running with a new project. All-in-all I would recommend this course to anyone who, like me, wants to know more about the what and whys of Typescript. It is also useful for anyone with a desire to know the age of the presenter...

results.content:
Der Moderator springt zu schnell im Code herum, was das ein bisschen unübersichtlich macht. Der Moderator sollte dem Zuschauer ein bisschen Zeit geben, das gerade gesagte aufzunehmen und zu verarbeiten.
Code-Completion ist beim Entwickeln sicher hilfreich, jedoch hat es hier im Video öfter gestört, weil es die Code-Zeile verdeckt.
Der Moderator sollte immer darauf hinweisen, wo er gerade hinspringt, sonst verliert der Zuschauer den Überblick.

results.content:
I just have finished the 9 module and I can only say that its WORTH IT. The drag and drop project has been really nice from several perspectives. The main ones are that you are applying Typescript in a project that has a little bit complexity, is not just a simple demo project and on the other hand the code is so clean or at least the instructor puts an effort to make it reusable(this super valuable in this industry).

I have took a look into the next lectures too see the next steps in the course and I can not be more pleased. Modules and Webpack are basic stuff to use typescript in a production project but typescript with React or Node.JS+express is like a bonus. I really appreciate it.

Thanks :)
results.content_html:
I just have finished the 9 module and I can only say that its WORTH IT. The drag and drop project has been really nice from several perspectives. The main ones are that you are applying Typescript in a project that has a little bit complexity, is not just a simple demo project and on the other hand the code is so clean or at least the instructor puts an effort to make it reusable(this super valuable in this industry).

I have took a look into the next lectures too see the next steps in the course and I can not be more pleased. Modules and Webpack are basic stuff to use typescript in a production project but typescript with React or Node.JS+express is like a bonus. I really appreciate it.

Thanks :)

results.content:
The basics you need to start-up in TypeScript.
Target people who never wrote one line of typeScript.
Does not reach you to a "full project" creation but cover all typeScript features, explaining briefly why it should be useful and how you should use it with basic use case.

Courses are well prepared and understandable, orator does a great job here. 

Courses was written with TypeScript 1.x but did not have issue to follow-up with TypeScript 2.x.
Some additional videos reflect changes specifics to typeScript 2.x.

results.content:
Excellent TypeScript course. I took a break from Max's Angular comprehensive course to study TS first, and I recommend anyone to do the same. Although I knew the basics, I wanted to be confident with concepts like decorators before learning Angular. 

This is a pretty typical use case for learning TS, but I also recognize its fantastic value even without Angular. I have personally never liked JavaScript's lack of strict typing, but my career made me a web developer, so I dealt with it. Oh the woes that JS types have caused me over the years when debugging.

As for Max's presentation, fantastic as usual. I have no complaints about his teaching style, the course structure, or the depth of material covered. I have yet to see a course from Max that isn't deserving of five-stars. 

An extension of the section on compiler options and further discussion of possibly useful alternate configurations might be useful to some.

My only real complaint is the lack of captions. Captions help me focus and prevent my eyes from wandering and finding distractions when there isn't much happening on the screen. I think it is only a professional courtesy that all paid-for productions like this should include captions. Auto-generated captions are next to useless for technical jargon and fast speakers.

results.content: I liked this course, but I didn't like the fact that some important features like Generics and Decorators did not have a lot of examples backing them up. About modules, I think there should be a better description of the now standard ES6 modules, AMD modules, CommonJS and so on to avoid confusion when googling for answers. And Webpack should probably be used from the beginning. Nevertheless, the course is fine, it explains everything you can find in the official documentation and it has the right pace.

results.content:
This was the first online course I have ever taken. At the beginning I did not know what to expect or how the lecturing would be done. I was glad to find out that throughout the whole course there were countess examples and everything that was taught was implemented in one way or another into code. I also have to congratulate Max since he was a great teacher and the way he modeled the course was very good for learning. All in all this is a great course if you care to learn Typescript. I am not leaving a perfect 5 star rating because at one point in the course he used async functions and it peaked my interest, however he did not elaborate further. Since I do not have any Javascript background I think it would be nice if there were one or two modules where the async functionality is explained.

In conclusion, I am really pleased with this course and I feel like I have actually gotten the grasp of Typescript and could actually use it in projects. 
I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is interested in learning Typescript.

results.content:
It's a good crash course for experienced programmers who understand the fundamentals of good object oriented SOLID principles. 

Lots of typescript concepts such as generics and interfaces mirrors C# which I have a lot of experience in.

However, I believe less experienced programmers will find the material presented a bit hard to apply on their own.

So, WTG, Max!

results.content:
This course was a very good intro to all aspects of Typescript including integration with React and using Typescript with gulp and webpack.  If you don't already know gulp, webpack or React (I didn't) those modules might be a bit difficult to follow.

Overall though, if you know nothing about Typescript and are looking for a broad introduction to the key parts of it, this is an excellent course.
results.content_html:
This course was a very good intro to all aspects of Typescript including integration with React and using Typescript with gulp and webpack. If you don't already know gulp, webpack or React (I didn't) those modules might be a bit difficult to follow.

Overall though, if you know nothing about Typescript and are looking for a broad introduction to the key parts of it, this is an excellent course.

results.content: Max has a unique way of explaining some concepts. For instance, he describes interfaces as contracts to define and conform to an API and then presents ways to write code that deviates from that API format. I don't find clarity between the explanation of abstract methods and interfaces

results.content:
Until lecture 9, there is no real good hands on example. This means the first 9 hours you only listen to the specific syntax of typescript. Thats boring. It's like reading  "The TypeScript Handbook". 

In my point of view "Decorators" are explained to early. This stuff is realy advanced, like annotations / AOP in Java or metaprogramming in ruby. So it should come later within the course with a little bit more details and examples around it. For newcomers the concept of class decorations is hard to grasp. It's different to the common case where instances are decorated.

results.content: Starts off very strong, but towards the middle of the course it dips off as the complexity increases. For example, the Drag & Drop is one of the weakest sections in the course because we're not given any idea of the application flow. A diagram (or diagrams) would have cleared up how the app would be structured, how it manages state, and how the logic flows. So much time was spent on this particular section (9), but so little time was spent on the planning (or at least informing the student about the plan) that it becomes too confusing to follow. In addition, a significant portion of this course focuses on experimental decorators. While, for now, they're able to be implemented; in the future, they may be dropped. So implementing them into an application may be a fools errand.
results.content_html: Starts off very strong, but towards the middle of the course it dips off as the complexity increases. For example, the Drag & Drop is one of the weakest sections in the course because we're not given any idea of the application flow. A diagram (or diagrams) would have cleared up how the app would be structured, how it manages state, and how the logic flows. So much time was spent on this particular section (9), but so little time was spent on the planning (or at least informing the student about the plan) that it becomes too confusing to follow. In addition, a significant portion of this course focuses on experimental decorators. While, for now, they're able to be implemented; in the future, they may be dropped. results.content: I've done several of Max's courses and they never fail to deliver a thorough overview of the subject and this one is no exception. Max seems to cover everything and often flys through things a bit, meaning you might have to pause and rewatch parts. This course is mainly theory and perhaps isn't therefore great fun, but the knowledge base it provides is outstanding. I'd probably rate this higher if it was the first course of Max's that I'd done, but being familiar with his work, the rating of "Good, what I expected", is fitting.

results.content:
Excellent overview of the language features. The course is well structured and presented in a clear, concise manner. The host is thorough and never really gets sidetracked or bogged down in minutia. 

The exercises really reinforce the concepts taught without being overwhelming, and the followup solution videos help to correct any issues and cement in the concepts. 

The one criticism I have is that some examples in the videos could be thought out better.
results.content_html:

results.content: Was a good course overall but if you don't know classes well it's a little tough to follow.  That said, it was interesting to see Max's approach to building a class based app which gave me insight into how frameworks like React work under the hood.  It was pretty boring in parts but lets face it, TypeScript isn't the most exciting topic.  Worth taking for intermediate devs, thanks!

That said, it was interesting to see Max's approach to building a class based app which gave me insight into how frameworks like React work under the hood. It was pretty boring in parts but lets face it, TypeScript isn't the most exciting topic. Worth taking for intermediate devs, thanks!

results.content: Overall a great course and Max as always is a wonderful instructor since he takes the time to show both old ways and more modern ways of using the tools he shows. I find it very easy to learn thoroughly from Max. I would have liked to see some assignments in the course because I really learn a lot from them from other courses I’ve taken from Max. The main reason I gave the course a 4 is not Max’s fault though. I find taking courses from Udemy in general on my iPad Air 2 cumbersome because of the several glitches with the app. There are several times when the video buffer gets more content the video backs up and replays a few seconds or worse yet freezes but runs out the timer so I’ll have to rewind to the exact time the buffer ran out to get the rest of the video going again. Also the docs lessons will sometimes not load any or only partially load and assignments are still not supported in the mobile app. These issues have been present for a couple years now since I’ve started using Udemy and I’ve reported on them a few times. It would be nice if they would be fixed.

results.content:
A really good course that's given me the knowledge I was looking for. For me, each topic had the right level of depth and pace.

I came to the course as someone with a Microsoft .net background who is in the process of learning Angular. So while I was familiar with the concepts of generics and classes, etc. from C#, I wanted to give myself a better foundation in TypeScript to help with learning Angular. This course has given me that foundation to build on, as well as the option to use TypeScript outside the Angular world. 

I'm sure I'll return to particular sections for reference in the future. Thanks a lot Max!

results.content: This has been an outstanding course for learning more about Typescript.  We have switched to Typescript at work for all of our mobile and backend development but since I work mainly on robot code today in a proprietary language I have not had much chance to use or learn Typescript.  This course is definitely improving my understanding and usage of the language and allows for me to more easily understand PR's when I am reviewing them.  Highly encourage anyone that is unfamiliar with strongly typed languages to take this course.  It is also helping me to better read code snippets from other languages like Java as concepts are similar such as abstract classes and interfaces

results.content:
Poor(0) number of assignments till now(Lecture 107)! It could be a lot better by applying the knowledge of every lecture or module with a number of exercises so somebody could see if he really understands what he learns at different sections of the course. 
Different exercises with different scenarios would be a good idea though since the concept of types is fairly new to programmers without any prior knowledge with typed languages like C/C++! 
Max is a great instructor and I've taken many of his courses. My comment does not have to do with the capabilities of the instructor to deliver a well-organized product, which apart from my comment this course is indeed well organized, but with the ability of the current course to truly pass down the knowledge of typescript to a beginner level typescript programmer though.
Recommendation: More assignments
Disclaimer: I am not here to scary people away of course.
Get this course, you're gonna learn a lot!

results.content:
Having a background in software development, I already had a pretty good concept of types and how they work, so the beginning on the course was perhaps a bit "dull", atleast to me. However it quickly picked up dramatically with all the more advanced types of TS. All in all, I think it was a good course. I feel like I have a good idea of how TS works, and how to use it. 

If going for a 5 star review I would probably add a couple code challenges in the later part of it, especially the "practice time" sections. It's a good way to force people to try to solve it themselves before seeing how you solve it. While their solutions might be completely wrong and they may give up its still a good way to try and make people think about solving the issue with TS.

results.content: Max is a great teacher and communicator. Having done a few courses on Udemy and a few free courses on YouTube it is hard to come across a developer that can communicate effectively and cover the small details of implementation. There were very, VERY, few moments where I had to jump outside of the course for clarification on a certain topic and it never was for something major. After finishing the course I would recommend this more for developers interested in understanding the underlying principles of TS and working on the Frontend. The Node and React sections are very small compared to the rest of the course, since it is TS course, not a React or Node course. This course is a START for using TS in your projects and I am confident you can understand any TS that gets sent your way after completing this course. I wanted to harness the power of TS on the Backend, and I will give NestJS a go by myself which I feel confident about after finishing this course. I will definitely favor courses coming from Max over others after this experience.

results.content:
First part until part 6 NOT for experienced developers! 

From Unit 1-5 the instructor is very explicit in his explanations. To the point of boredom...As experienced developer i simply recommend to read the typescript documentation. 

This however changes with the beginning of unit 6:
Here modules and namespaces are explained, followed by interfaces, contracts and generics and how to use Typescript with third party libraries etc..
I still miss a part about unit-testing, but with the given information, this should not be too hard to find out. The instructor is very competent!

results.content: I've learned a lot here on Udemy the last couple of years, and one of them is that Max always delivers the goods, and this course is certainly no exception. My very first course on Udemy was this one, and now I found out that Max just marked all the lessons in it as "legacy", and went ahead and added a full set of completely new lessons, essentially replacing the entire course with a brand new one. There was nothing wrong with the old one, he kept it updated where it mattered, but he just made a new one anyway, with more topics and more content, completely free for those who had already bought the old course. Seriously, who does that? His courses are so good I'd probably have paid for the new version with a big smile on my face, but no, here you go, free because why the hell not. If I wasn't already a huge fan of Max as an instructor and course creator, including his Academind YouTube-channel, I certainly would have become one now.

There was nothing wrong with the old one, he kept it updated where it mattered, but he just made a new one anyway, with more topics and more content, completely free for those who had already bought the old course. Seriously, who does that? His courses are so good I'd probably have paid for the new version with a big smile on my face, but no, here you go, free because why the hell not. If I wasn't already a huge fan of Max as an instructor and course creator, including his Academind YouTube-channel, I certainly would have become one now.

results.content:
The course was generally good, and I definitely learned a little more about TypeScript that I (would guess) I need to move on to ng2. However, I do not feel completely confident in my knowledge about the language.

It would help to dive deeper into the WHY of using the new features of TypeScript. Why would I use decorators, why would I use generics, and in what specific cases would using these features be preferable over solving the problem in any other way? If the why can be explained in a more detail and contrasted with another way of solving the problem, this could would easily be 5+ stars.

results.content:
Excellent delivery of concepts.
Short and crisp exercise.
To the point explanation.  
A great course for absolute beginner, at the the end you will have enough knowledge to become a intermediate typescript developer.

Cons
The course is still using older version of type script. I have missed many new concept and many places the guidance was not matching with the latest.
Interface, Generic and Decorator should have detail explanation and more real time example/use-case.
I think the react chapter would be more improved if you discuss how React has utilize Typescript with little explanation.

Overall It is great course. I had started with zero knowledge and gained enough confidence to write Typescript code.
results.content_html:
Excellent delivery of concepts.

Cons

Interface, Generic and Decorator should have detail explanation and more real time example/use-case.
I think the react chapter would be more improved if you discuss how React has utilize Typescript with little explanation.

Overall It is great course. I had started with zero knowledge and gained enough confidence to write Typescript code.

results.content: The course gives a packed introduction into what typescript is and some examples where and how to use it and I was mostly happy with how the modules were structured and paced. I felt that the demo projects were a bit too simple logic and structure-wise but I guess the limitation is understandable in order to keep the scope narrow. If you're good at reading documentations and experimenting yourself you might find it suitable to just dive into the official typescript documentations and experiment yourself but for people who prefer concise video instructions I can recommend this course.

If you're good at reading documentations and experimenting yourself you might find it suitable to just dive into the official typescript documentations and experiment yourself but for people who prefer concise video instructions I can recommend this course.

results.content: I really love Max's way of teaching. This course is a bit advanced and he does not go into so much detail like in other courses. If you don't have any prior Javascript experience, this is not the course for you. I liked it because it was a bit shorter and had a faster pace. It's similar in that way with his VueJs bootcamp, a course that helped me a great deal since I had just started using Vue at work. So all in all I found the course very helpful, I'd love a testing section in the near future.

results.content:
Great course quality overall. Well structured, nice exercises and simple examples are used across the lectures to help you to wrap your head around complex concepts.

To make this course even better, I'd personally add more optional advanced tasks to challenge the experienced viewer. Some of the examples, for instance in the "decorators" section, are maybe too simple for people who have already  computer science background. But hey, this is *understanding* typescript, isn't it? :)

I totally recommend it!

results.content: Very good at explaining topics but I really disliked the way the course was laid out. There were too many modules and not enough checks within each one in that if you made an error in some config file you'd have to go back to the beginning and go though each step again to figure out where you went wrong. It would be nice to have checks in each module so that you know when you move to the next you're ready to continue. Also, would have been nice if there was a more robust example project to work through using TS just to get a better idea of how to apply. Again, the instructor was very enthusiastic and well spoken.
results.content_html: Very good at explaining topics but I really disliked the way the course was laid out. There were too many modules and not enough checks within each one in that if you made an error in some config file you'd have to go back to the beginning and go though each step again to figure out where you went wrong. It would be nice to have checks in each module so that you know when you move to the next you're ready to continue. Also, would have been nice if there was a more robust example project to work through using TS just to get a better idea of how to apply. Again, the instructor was very enthusiastic and well spoken.

results.content:
I was looking for a straight forward course that would teach me, in an easy to understand way, the ins and outs of Typescript. 

I wanted to know how to be effective and successful with Typescript, and not a historian in this language and capable of maintaining old / legacy code.

As an entrepreneur, I don't want to know a lot of ways to solve the same problem. I just need to know the most efficient and modern way. 

This course is great, but there is too much "noise" for entrepreneurs.  

Unfortunately, it's very difficult to find courses focused only on practical teachings to get things done in the most efficient way.
